challenges.title: CSS with Superpowers
description: Q: How can we write better CSS?
A: Use a preprocessor.
What are CSS preprocessors?
CSS preprocessors take code written in the preprocessed language and then convert that code into CSS. Pretty basic, right?
So what's the point of using one?

CSS preprocessors such as Sass or Less allow you to do nifty things that regular CSS can't do. They enable you to create variables, write more compact code with nesting, import other CSS files and much more.
In this series of Waypoints, we will be teaching you the basics of Sass

challenges.title: Storing Data with Sass Variables
description: Just like in Javascript, you can declare variables to store data in.
In JavaScript, you would use the var keyword to define a variable. When declaring variables in Sass, you start by using a $ followed by a string.
Here is an example: $color: green;

Making variables becomes exteremly useful when we want similar elements to have the same color, for example. If you wanted to change the color to a slightly different shade, all we would have to do is change the variable's value.
Instructions
Create a variable $text-color and set it equal to red
Then change the value of all color properties by using color: $text-color.
Finally, change the value of $text-color to another color and see how all respective elements change color!

challenges.title: Nesting your CSS
description: Nesting is a really useful way of organising your CSS.
Normally, you would target each element on a different line to style it, like so:

nav{
  background-color: red;
}

nav ul{
  list-style: none;
}

li{
  display: inline-block;
}

As you can imagine, in larger projects, your CSS file will get pretty messy. Here is where nesting comes in - it allows you to organise your different styles by nesting them within their respective parent elements:

nav{
  background-color: red;

  ul{
    list-style: none;

    li{
      display: inline-block;
    }
  }
}
Instructions
Use the nesting technique shown above to style both children of .blog-post. The h1 **tag** should be **centred** and be blue. The p **tag** should have a font size of 20px.

challenges.title: Mixing the Cake
description: A mixin lets you make groups of CSS declarations that you want to reuse throughout your site. Consider "box-shadow":

div{
  -webkit-box-shadow: 0px 0px 4px #fff
  -moz-box-shadow: 0px 0px 4px #fff
  -ms-box-shadow: 0px 0px 4px #fff
  box-shadow: 0px 0px 4px #fff
}
It would be really annyoing to re-write this over and over again for each element that we want to use box-shadow on, or having to change each value because we're testing different effects.
Thankfully, Sass has mixins - these are like functions for CSS. Here is how to write one:

@mixin box-shadow($x, $y, $blur, $c){
  -webkit-box-shadow: $x, $y, $blur, $c
  -moz-box-shadow: $x, $y, $blur, $c
  -ms-box-shadow: $x, $y, $blur, $c
  box-shadow: $x, $y, $blur, $c
}
You start by using the directive @mixin followed by a custom name. You can also include arguments as we have.
This way, we can use a single line: box-shadow and pass parameters without having to re-write all the vendor prefixes. Let's see how to use this:

div{
  @include box-shadow(0px, 0px, 4px, #fff)
}
Instructions
Write your own mixin for border-radius and give it a $radius parameter.
Then use border-radius to give #awesome a border radius of 10px.

challenges.title: Using @if and @else.
description: The @if directive is useful if you want to test for a specifc case - it works just like the if statement in JavaScript

@mixin make-bold($bool){
  @if $bool == bold { font-weight: bold }
}
And just like in Javascript, we can also add @else if and @else to test for more conditions.

@mixin text-effect($val){
  @if $val == danger {color: red}
  @else if $val == alert {color: yellow}
  @else if $val == success {color: green}
  @else {color: black}
}
Instructions
Make a mixin called border-stroke that takes an argument of $val. The mixin should check for the following conditions using @else if and @else:

light - 1px solid black
medium - 3px solid black
heavy - 6px solid black
none - no border

challenges.title: Continuing with @for
description: The @for directive allows you to add styles in a loop - just like a for loop in JavaScript.

We can use @for in 2 different ways: "start through end" or "start to end". The main difference is that "start to end" will exclude the ending number while "start through end" will include the ending number.
Let's take a look at a start through end example:

@for $i from 1 through 12 {
  .col-#{$i} { width: 100/12 * $i; }
}
This will produce the following:

.col-1 {
  width: 8.33333;
}

.col-2 {
  width: 16.66667;
}
And so on till .col-12. This is a really powerful way of getting a grid layout.
Instructions
Make a @for directive that takes a variable $j that goes from 1 to 6.
This should create 5 classes called .text-1 through .text-5 that makes the font-size: 10 * the number.

challenges.title: Expanding with @each
description: The @each directive uses a list or map instead of starting and ending values like the @for directive.
On each iteration, the variable gets assigned to a value from the list or map.

@each $color in blue, red, green {
  .#{$color}-text {color: $color}
}
We can also use a map instead of a list:
$colors: (color1: blue, color2: red, color3: green);

@each $key, $color in $colors {
  .#{$color}-text {color: $color}
}
We need to add a $key variable to referance the keys in the map. Else, our complied CSS would have color1, color2.... in it.
Both of the above code will output:

.blue-text {
  color: blue;
}

.red-text {
  color: red;
}
Instructions
Make an @each directive that goes through a list: blue, black, red and assigns each variable to a ."color"-bg class.
Each class should make the background-color the respective color.

challenges.title: Wrapping up with @while
description: The last directive we will talk about is the @while directive.
Remember how we made a simple grid system using @for? Well, here is the same thing with @while.

$x: 1;
@while $x < 13 {
&npsp; .col-#{$x} { width: 100/12 * $x;}
  $x: $x + 1;
};
We first define a variable $x and set it to 1. We then use the @while directive to create the grid system while $x is less than 13.
After genreating the CSS, we increment $x by 1 as to avoid an infinite loop!
This is another way of creating a gid system in Sass.
Instructions
Use @while to generate classes that will be used to manipulate font-size.
Their should be 10 different classes named text-"number here" that set font-size to the repective number in px.

challenges.title: Extend your CSS styles
description: Imagine you have a piece of CSS that styles a .panel class. It might have a background-color, height and border for example.
Now lets say we want to have another panel called .big-panel but have the same base properties as .panel, but also have a width and font-size.
We could copy/paste the initial code from .panel but if we also wanted another type of panel, things would get repetitive very quickly.
This is where extend jumps in. In the case of .panel:

.panel{
  background-color: red;
  height: 70px;
  border: 2px solid green;
}
We can now extend .panel instead of copy/pasting the code:

.big-panel{
  @extend .panel
  width: 150px;
  font-size: 2em;
}
And .big-panel will have the same properties as .panel including its own styles.
Instructions
Make a class .info-important that extends .info and also has a background-color.
